title: How to Make Spiced Figs

steps.headline: Soak for one hour in enough cold water to cover.
Drain after one hour and place into a saucepan with the vinegar and sugar.
Make a spice bag using a piece of cheesecloth.
steps.description: Add the cloves, cinnamon pieces and tie with string.

steps.headline: Put the spice bag into the saucepan with the figs.
Cook together for 50 minutes or until the figs become tender.
Serve.
steps.description: Place in small dessert bowls and add whipped cream if wished.

steps.headline: Add the figs to a large mixing bowl.
steps.description: Pour the warm water over the top. Let stand overnight, covered.

steps.headline: Place the sugar, cold water and a quarter of the orange juice into the saucepan.
steps.description: Cook over medium heat for 5 minutes, stirring to help dissolve the sugar.

steps.headline: Allow to gently simmer for 50 minutes.
steps.description: Check now and then but do not stir. Cook until the color turns golden.

steps.headline: Remove from the heat.
steps.description: Pour in the rest of the orange juice; be aware it may spit, so do this at arm's length.

steps.headline: Return the saucepan to the stovetop.
steps.description: Heat on low. Add the star anise and the soaked figs. Cover and simmer for 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove from the heat.
steps.description: Transfer the spiced figs to sterilized jars. Seal. Turn upside down and let sit like that for 20 minutes. Turn back upright after 20 minutes and leave to cool.

steps.headline: Add a label with the date and contents.
steps.description: Place in a cool, dark place to store.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: To serve, simply spoon figs into a dessert bowl and add your topping of choice. Toppings that match well include ice cream, heavy cream, custard and pureed berries.

text: Fresh spiced figs Wash the figs.  Soak for one hour in enough cold water to cover.  Drain after one hour and place into a saucepan with the vinegar and sugar.  Make a spice bag using a piece of cheesecloth. Add the cloves, cinnamon pieces and tie with string. Put the spice bag into the saucepan with the figs.  Cook together for 50 minutes or until the figs become tender.  Serve. Place in small dessert bowls and add whipped cream if wished. Semi-dried spiced figs Add the figs to a large mixing bowl. Pour the warm water over the top. Let stand overnight, covered. Drain the soaked figs.  Place the sugar, cold water and a quarter of the orange juice into the saucepan. Cook over medium heat for 5 minutes, stirring to help dissolve the sugar. Allow to gently simmer for 50 minutes. Check now and then but do not stir. Cook until the color turns golden. Remove from the heat. Pour in the rest of the orange juice; be aware it may spit, so do this at arm's length. Return the saucepan to the stovetop. Heat on low. Add the star anise and the soaked figs. Cover and simmer for 10 minutes. Remove from the heat. Transfer the spiced figs to sterilized jars. Seal. Turn upside down and let sit like that for 20 minutes. Turn back upright after 20 minutes and leave to cool. Add a label with the date and contents. Place in a cool, dark place to store. Serve. To serve, simply spoon figs into a dessert bowl and add your topping of choice. Toppings that match well include ice cream, heavy cream, custard and pureed berries.
